description: Easy - Plebeian Pressure and Patrician Resistance

questions.question: After the Gallic invasion was repelled, what did plebeians do immediately?
options: They accepted patrician rule permanently and stopped demanding political rights
They resumed their demands for political access with renewed intensity
They moved out of Rome and established a separate plebeian city
They allied with the Gauls and threatened to invite them back
questions.text_reference: Section 3: The Resumption of Political Demands

questions.question: What major plebeian demand involved access to religious authority in Rome?
options: The right to establish their own plebeian temples and priesthoods completely separate from patricians
Access to priesthoods like augurs and pontifices that had been exclusively patrician
The right to veto all patrician religious ceremonies through tribune power
The ability to replace the patrician-controlled religious calendar with a new one
questions.text_reference: Section 3: Demands for Access to Priesthoods

questions.question: Which office symbolically represented plebeian equality more than any other?
options: The Tribune of the Plebs because it was plebeian in origin
The Censor because it controlled census and property records
The Praetor because it involved military command in the field
The Consulship because it was the highest office and symbol of political authority
questions.text_reference: Section 3: Demands for Access to Magistracies

questions.question: What specific magistracies did plebeians demand access to?
options: Only the consulship and no other offices
Quaestorships, praetorships, aedileships, and the consulship
Only military positions and not civilian magistracies
All offices except the dictator, which remained patrician only
questions.text_reference: Section 3: Demands for Access to Magistracies

questions.question: What did patricians claim about their natural right to hold high office?
options: They earned offices through military victories and nothing else
They claimed noble lineage, special religious knowledge, and ancestral tradition justified exclusive rule
They argued that plebeians were too poor to pay for the costs of holding office
They said the gods had revealed that only patricians could govern Rome

questions.question: What Latin phrase did patricians invoke to defend their exclusive privileges?
options: Imperium supremum (supreme power)
Auctoritas maxima (greatest authority)
Mos maiorum (the way of the ancestors)
Potestas populi (power of the people)

questions.question: What was the political situation in Rome for decades after the Gallic invasion?
options: Patricians had completely surrendered to plebeian demands and shared all power
Plebeians had captured power and ruled Rome exclusively without patrician input
A stalemate where neither side could force the other to capitulate
The two groups had completely separated and governed different parts of Rome

questions.question: Why were patricians willing to make small concessions to plebeian demands rather than accept large reforms?
options: They wanted to maintain their power while appeasing discontent through limited change
They were creating new offices like the praetorship that plebeians could eventually access
They feared a full plebeian revolt would destroy the Republic entirely
They believed plebeians lacked the intelligence to hold higher offices

questions.question: What was the plebeian response to patrician claims about ancestry and religious knowledge?
options: They agreed completely and stopped asking for political office
They asked how patricians could claim to be fit rulers if they had led Rome to catastrophic military defeat
They said genealogy did not matter as much as military victories in battle
They proposed eliminating all magistracies and creating a democracy

questions.question: What power did plebeians threaten repeatedly during this period of negotiation?
options: The threat to become mercenaries for foreign powers and abandon Rome
The threat of military secessionâ€”refusing to serve in Rome's armies
The threat to invade the Forum and forcibly seize political power
The threat to migrate to a neighboring Italian city-state and start a rival Rome
